hedline.hl1: The Nation; What Makes Soft Money Soft?

abstract.p: Article on difference between hard and soft money in light of Rep Rick Lazio's challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton not to use any soft money in New York State Senate campaign; photo (S)

block.p: ONCE, there was the smoke-filled room. These days, unsavory politics is epitomized with the phrase soft money.

So far, much more hard money has been spent on the New York Senate race than soft money. But at their first debate last week, Representative Rick A. Lazio strode over to Hillary Rodham Clinton's lectern and asked her to sign a pledge against taking soft money. She demurred, calling him the real soft-money scofflaw.
ONCE, there was the smoke-filled room. These days, unsavory politics is epitomized with the phrase soft money.

So far, much more hard money has been spent on the New York Senate race than soft money. But at their first debate last week, Representative Rick A. Lazio strode over to Hillary Rodham Clinton's lectern and asked her to sign a pledge against taking soft money. She demurred, calling him the real soft-money scofflaw.

Soft money is a contribution to political parties, rather than to the candidates themselves. It is supposed to pay only for party activities, like voter drives. But the parties have found ways to channel the money to help candidates, usually by buying commercials. (Some definitions also consider spending by outside groups unconnected to the parties as soft money.) There is no ceiling on soft money donations. Moreover, unions and corporations, which are barred from donating hard dollars in federal elections, can give soft ones.
The term may have been invented to contrast with hard dollars that candidates collect directly, though some advocates of campaign finance reform think the term doesn't sound nefarious enough.
